About Ricochet Robots

Know more

What is Ricochet Robots?

Ricochet robots is a fun puzzle game.

The goal is to get the maximum amount of points possible. Points are achieved by solving the puzzle more efficiently than the other players.

About MY Ricochet robots

After playing this board game I was inspired to create my own digital version (trying to be as close to the original as possible). The program was created using Pygame for the base. The little icons are the same as in the original game (but I have in mind changing them a little to match my version of penguins on ice, instead of robots). Everything else (other than the board configuration) was drawn and coded by me. It was a fun project with many things to learn, from use of OOP and use of geometry in a computer game to organization of the code, and lastly (unfortunately, since this is my first personal project), setting realistic goals, instead of a unique big and ambitious goal.

Evolution of the project

The initial idea was to create a game that, even with simple rules, can present a huge variety of scenarios. The board consists of 8 different pieces, each of them with two faces. The order is not fixed and the creation of the board is almost totally free. This gives over 1,500 configurations. But making it possible to move the pieces according to the rules and detect when the goal is achieved has its tricks. That is when I noticed I had to be more realistic with my project, or at least having better short term goals. The game still needs a few adjustments to be playable. The current goal is to reduce the complexity and once it is totally playable with 1 board, start adding features (like the option to move back pieces in case of error, including more boards, the black piece and other things).

Things I have learned

I have learned to break my big goal into several smaller ones. To take more care of the organization of the code. To use inheritance and other OOP topics. It is fun to build everything by yourself, but it is also an option to use more libraries (for example PyQT5, which I used in my multiclip project). I think that both options have pros and cons.
